headline.seo: Registering to Donate Organs Can Be Off-Putting
headline.print_headline: Why New Yorkers Don’t Donate Organs
headline.main: Why New Yorkers Don’t Donate Organs

docs.lead_paragraph: Joining New York State’s organ donor registry requires a mail-in form and can prompt graphic images.
docs.snippet: Joining New York State’s organ donor registry requires a mail-in form and can prompt graphic images.

headline.print_headline: A Tax to Combat America’s Sugary Diet
headline.main: A Tax to Combat America’s Sugary Diet

docs.lead_paragraph: To improve the health of its residents and its coffers, New York State, among others, is considering an excise tax of about one penny per ounce on high-calorie sweetened beverages.
docs.snippet: To improve the health of its residents and its coffers, New York State, among others, is considering an excise tax of about one penny per ounce on high-calorie sweetened beverages.

headline.main: After 176 Years, Mouth Returns to Face

docs.abstract: Also in Morning Buzz today: Haitian-American doctors and nurses are traveling to their homeland en masse to help out; a chat with the soda tax's most vocal proponent; and other regional news.
docs.lead_paragraph: Finding a politician's mouth has rarely been a problem -- unless it has been missing since 1834.
docs.snippet: Also in Morning Buzz today: Haitian-American doctors and nurses are traveling to their homeland en masse to help out; a chat with the soda tax's most vocal proponent; and other regional news.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Senate bill would set much-needed nutritional standards for the more than 30 million lunches served each school day to children across the country.
docs.snippet: A Senate bill would set much-needed nutritional standards for the more than 30 million lunches served each school day to children across the country.

headline.seo: New York Health Official Champions the Soda Tax
headline.print_headline: Health Official Willing to Go to the Mat Over Obesity and Sugared Sodas
headline.main: Health Official Willing to Go to the Mat Over Obesity and Sugared Sodas

docs.lead_paragraph: New York’s health commissioner has been lobbying anyone who would listen about the scourge of obesity and championing the proposed soda tax as a possible cure.
docs.snippet: New York’s health commissioner has been lobbying anyone who would listen about the scourge of obesity and championing the proposed soda tax as a possible cure.

headline.print_headline: New Health Initiatives Put Spotlight on Prevention
headline.main: New Health Initiatives Put Spotlight on Prevention

docs.lead_paragraph: With little fanfare, Congress approved wide-ranging plans to prevent disease and encourage healthy behavior.
docs.snippet: With little fanfare, Congress approved wide-ranging plans to prevent disease and encourage healthy behavior.

headline.print_headline: Richmond’s New Priority: Taking Health Seriously
headline.main: Richmond’s New Priority: Taking Health Seriously

docs.lead_paragraph: Richmond is close to adopting a new vision for itself that makes the health of its residents a top priority.
docs.snippet: Richmond is close to adopting a new vision for itself that makes the health of its residents a top priority.

docs.abstract: President Obama tried to build unity in his holiday address Saturday morning by raising the issues of health care, education and job security as core America values.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the country continues to split over the administration's health care bill, President Obama tried to build unity among "Jews and Christians, Muslims and Hindus, believers and nonbelievers alike" in his national address the day before Easter.
docs.snippet: President Obama tried to build unity in his holiday address Saturday morning by raising the issues of health care, education and job security as core America values.

headline.main: What It Takes to Fight Obesity

docs.abstract: Room for Debate readers on their struggles with weight and ways to keep the pounds off.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Room for Debate forum last week discussed the effectiveness of public campaigns to promote healthy eating and reduce obesity. Many readers wrote in about their own struggles with weight, what worked for them and how public policy might be changed to help Americans keep the pounds off. Here are excerpts from their comments.
docs.snippet: Room for Debate readers on their struggles with weight and ways to keep the pounds off.

docs.abstract: Your Jokes | So the deal is, we buy health insurance or pay a fine or go to jail, where health care is free. That must be your public option right there. -- Will Durst, San Francisco
docs.lead_paragraph: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:
